# List of NCAA Division I men's basketball champions

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![A room with glass display cases containing rectangular, wooden trophies
that are gold-
plated.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/NCAA_titles.jpg/250px-
NCAA_titles.jpg)](/wiki/File:NCAA_titles.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NCAA_titles.jpg "Enlarge")

The [University of California, Los
Angeles](/wiki/UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball "UCLA Bruins men's basketball")
(trophy room pictured) has won the Men's Division I Basketball Championship a
record 11 times.

This is a **list of NCAA Division I men 's basketball champions**. The
[National Collegiate Athletic
Association](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National
Collegiate Athletic Association") (NCAA) [Men's Division I Basketball
Championship](/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship "NCAA
Men's Division I Basketball Championship"), or NCAA Tournament, is a [single-
elimination tournament](/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament "Single-
elimination tournament") for men's [college
basketball](/wiki/College_basketball "College basketball") teams in the United
States. It determines the champion of [Division I](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I "NCAA
Division I"), the top level of play in the NCAA,[1] and the media often
describes the winner as the national champion of college basketball.[2][3] The
NCAA Tournament has been held annually since 1939, and its field grew from
eight teams in the beginning to sixty-five teams by 2001; as of 2011, sixty-
eight teams take part in the tournament.[4][5] Teams can [gain
invitations](/wiki/NCAA_basketball_tournament_selection_process "NCAA
basketball tournament selection process") by winning a conference championship
or receiving an [at-large bid](/wiki/At-large_bid "At-large bid") from a
10-person committee.[6] The semifinals of the tournament are known as the
[Final Four](/wiki/Final_Four "Final Four") and are held in a different city
each year, along with the championship game;[7]
[Indianapolis](/wiki/Indianapolis "Indianapolis"), the city where the NCAA is
based, will host the Final Four every five years until 2040.[8] Each winning
university receives a rectangular, gold-plated trophy made of wood.[9]

The [first NCAA
Tournament](/wiki/1939_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "1939
NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament") was organized by the [National
Association of Basketball
Coaches](/wiki/National_Association_of_Basketball_Coaches "National
Association of Basketball Coaches").[10]
[Oregon](/wiki/Oregon_Ducks_men%27s_basketball "Oregon Ducks men's
basketball") won the inaugural tournament, defeating [Ohio
State](/wiki/Ohio_State_Buckeyes_men%27s_basketball "Ohio State Buckeyes men's
basketball") 46–33 in the first championship game. Before the 1941 tournament,
control of the event was given to the NCAA.[10] In the early years of the
tournament, it was considered less important than the [National Invitation
Tournament](/wiki/National_Invitation_Tournament "National Invitation
Tournament") (NIT), a New York City-based event.[11][12] Teams were able to
compete in both events in the same year, and three of those that did
so—[Utah](/wiki/Utah_Utes_men%27s_basketball "Utah Utes men's basketball") in
1944, [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball "Kentucky Wildcats
men's basketball") in 1949, and [City College of New
York](/wiki/City_College_of_New_York "City College of New York") (CCNY) in
1950—won the NCAA Tournament.[13] The [1949–50 CCNY
team](/wiki/1949%E2%80%9350_CCNY_Beavers_men%27s_basketball_team "1949–50 CCNY
Beavers men's basketball team") won both tournaments (defeating
[Bradley](/wiki/Bradley_Braves_men%27s_basketball "Bradley Braves men's
basketball") in both finals), and is the only college basketball team to
accomplish this feat.[14] By the mid-1950s, the NCAA Tournament became the
more prestigious of the two events,[15] and in 1971 the NCAA barred
universities from playing in other tournaments, such as the NIT, if they were
invited to the NCAA Tournament.[16]

The [University of California, Los
Angeles](/wiki/UCLA_Bruins_men%27s_basketball "UCLA Bruins men's basketball")
(UCLA) has been the most successful college in the NCAA Tournament, winning 11
national titles. Ten of those championships came during a 12-year stretch from
1964 to 1975. UCLA also holds the record for the most consecutive
championships, winning seven in a row from 1967 to 1973. Kentucky has the
second-most titles, with eight. [North
Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina_Tar_Heels_men%27s_basketball "North Carolina
Tar Heels men's basketball") is third with six championships, while
[Duke](/wiki/Duke_Blue_Devils_men%27s_basketball "Duke Blue Devils men's
basketball") and [Indiana](/wiki/Indiana_Hoosiers_men%27s_basketball "Indiana
Hoosiers men's basketball") follow with five each.
[Villanova](/wiki/Villanova_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball "Villanova Wildcats
men's basketball") is the most recent champion, having defeated
[Michigan](/wiki/Michigan_Wolverines_men%27s_basketball "Michigan Wolverines
men's basketball") in the final of the 2018 tournament. Among [head
coaches](/wiki/Coach_\(basketball\) "Coach \(basketball\)"), [John
Wooden](/wiki/John_Wooden "John Wooden") is the all-time leader with 10
championships; he coached UCLA during their period of success in the 1960s and
1970s. Duke's [Mike Krzyzewski](/wiki/Mike_Krzyzewski "Mike Krzyzewski") is
second all-time with five titles.
